DOC.HEAD: Japanese Arrested With More Than 200 Endangered Reptiles
DOC.TEXT: A Japanese man was arrested at the international airport trying to smuggle nearly 300 endangered turtles and lizards to Japan in his suitcases, a police officer said today. Tsuyoshi Shirawa, 20, was arrested Sunday after authorities discovered that his four suitcases contained 98 turtles and 185 Oriental water lizards, said police Capt. Paiboon Arinchai. Shiwara told police he brought the reptiles from Malaysia and stopped in Bangkok to visit a friend en route to Japan. Convicted of possession of endangered wildlife on Monday, Shiwara received a three-month suspended prison sentence and was fined $100. Paiboon said the reptiles were tightly packed into the baggage and bound to prevent them from making noise and moving. Two turtles and one lizard died. Boonlerd Angsirijida, a Forestry Department official charged with wildlife conservation, said Japan was a major market for wildlife from Thailand, Indonesia, the Phillipines and South American countries. Last month, Japan returned to Thailand 58 wild animals that had been smuggled into Japan. Among these were white-handed gibbons, Burmese molurus pythons and slow loris monkeys. Thailand has been widely criticized as a major transit nation for illegal international trade in wildlife.
